channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Search for Missing Plane Called Off for Bad Weather
item.description: Severe weather in the southern Indian Ocean has made flying to the possible wreckage zone too risky for search crews.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER and MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: An inflatable boat was launched from an Australian Navy ship during the Indian Ocean search.

item.title: India Ink: Tribal Activist Candidate Poses a Problem for Aam Aadmi
item.description: In many ways, Soni Sori, who will run for Parliament in the central Indian state of Chhattisgarh, is a natural fit with the Aam Aadmi Party’s populist manifesto, but her candidacy has the potential to divide a party that is still searching for a core identity.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: Soni Sori, a tribal activist from Chhattisgarh, India, has been fielded by the Aam Aadmi Party from the Bastar constituency in the state.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Airline Buckles to Pressure From PETA on Monkey Cargo
item.description: PETA, the animal welfare organization that has campaigned for years against transporting animals for lab testing, says the change in China Southern’s policy could hamper efforts to use animals from Asia for experiments.
item.category: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals
item.dc:creator: By SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:description: A researcher injects a monkey with an experimental solution in Guangzhou.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Fissures in China’s Ethnic Policy
item.description: A spying incident at the United Nations by a representative of a group tied to the Communist Party’s United Front Work Department has cast a spotlight on a turf war over ethnic policy, scholars said.
item.category: China Assn for Preservation and Development of Tibetan Culture
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Paramilitary police patrolled a street near the Kunming train station after a deadly knifing rampage on March 1 that Chinese officials blamed on Xinjiang separatists.

item.title: Search for Lost Jet Is Complicated by Geopolitics and Rivalries
item.description: While the United States, China and others have collaborated in the search for the Malaysian plane, each in its own way has been hesitant to reveal the extent of its surveillance abilities.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: A relative of passengers on the missing Malaysia Airlines flight spoke to members of the news media on Wednesday at a hotel in Beijing.

item.title: ‘Environmental Poisoning’ of Iraq Is Claimed
item.description: An advocacy group said at a congressional hearing that veterans and civilians continued to feel the effects of burn pits used to dispose of military waste, and that Washington must aid sufferers.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JADA F. SMITH

item.title: Amnesty International Study Finds Executions Rose in 2013
item.description: Amnesty International’s report attributed most of the nearly 15 percent increase to “virtual killing sprees” carried out by Iran and Iraq, though the group considers China the world’s top executioner.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Zbigniew Romaszewski, Physicist Who Resisted Poland’s Communists, Dies at 74
item.description: He played an early role in a seminal workers’ rights group founded in the 1970s, which helped establish the Solidarity movement.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Zbigniew Romaszewski, center, and his wife Irena Zofia , in a Polish military court in Warsaw. The couple and seven other defendants were convicted of spreading false information and conducting illegal union activity by their work with an underground radio station.

item.title: The Lede: Belgian Paper Apologizes Over Racist Images of Obama Used in Satire
item.description: The newspaper De Morgen apologized to readers offended by a satirical feature that used racist images of President Obama mocking his strained relationship with the Russian president, Vladimir Putin.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: European Banks Feel Effects of Crimea Crisis, With Austria Bearing Brunt
item.description: Vienna's banks were not alone in staking out the former Soviet bloc. But for reasons of geography and history, they bet big on Eastern Europe.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING

item.title: The Lede: Heckling From Egyptian Activists as Military Leader Declares Presidential Ambition
item.description: Defense Minister Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi’s announcement that he will run for president was greeted with anger, dismay and sarcasm online by activists, rights workers and commentators who supported the 2011 revolution.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Amid New Rules and Scrutiny, Secret Service Confronts Agents’ Conduct
item.description: Questions arise again about whether the agency in charge of the president’s security has fostered a culture of debauchery.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.media:description: A member of a Secret Service team on Wednesday waited for President Obama in Brussels. On Sunday, team members were sent home for disciplinary reasons.

item.title: German Man to Return Nazi-Looted Art
item.description: Cornelius Gurlitt, the octogenarian hoarder of art plundered by the Nazis, will return the paintings to their original Jewish owners or those owners’ descendants.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY
item.media:credit: Staatsanwaltschaft Augsburg, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Artworks among the trove that Cornelius Gurlitt kept for years in his Munich apartment. From top left: "Don Quixote and Sancho Panza" by Honore Daumier, "Riders on the Beach" by Max Liebermann, "Study of a Woman Nude, Standing, Arms Raised, Hands Crossed Above Head" by Auguste Rodin, "Child at Table" by Otto Griebel, "Sa Giustina in Pra della Vale" by Antonio Canaletto, "Male Portrait" by Ludwig Godenschweg, "Couple" by Hans Christoph, "Mother and Child" by Erich Fraass, "Couple in a Landscape" by Conrad Felixmueller, "View of the Seine Valley" by Theodore Rousseau, "Monk" by Christoph Voll, "Tram" by Bernhard Kretschmar, "Thinking Woman" by Fritz Maskos, "The Master Exploder Hantsch" by Christoph Voll, "Female Nude" by Ludwig Godenschweg, "Seated Woman/Woman Sitting in Armchair" by Henri Matisse, "Veiled Woman" by Otto Griebel, "Girl at Table" by Wilhelm Lachnit, "Dompteuse" by Otto Dix, and "Male Nude" by Bonaventura Genelli.

item.title: Military Cuts Render NATO Less Formidable as Deterrent to Russia
item.description: President Obama and European leaders have pledged that Russia would not be allowed to run roughshod, but the military reality tells a different story.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER and STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers on Wednesday. Ukraine has started withdrawing its troops and weapons from Crimea, now controlled by Russia.

item.title: Indonesia Candidate Tied to Human Rights Abuses Stirs Unease
item.description: Prabowo Subianto, an ex-special forces commander accused of torture and abductions, has announced his candidacy for president, putting the Obama administration in a difficult position.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: Prabowo Subianto, front left, the presidential candidate for the Great Indonesia Movement Party, at a rally on Sunday in Jakarta.

item.title: Obama Renewing U.S. Commitment to NATO Alliance
item.description: In a sharp rebuke, President Obama, in Brussels, denounced Russia’s takeover of Crimea and described Moscow as an out-of-touch power.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and PETER BAKER
item.media:description: President Obama participated in a wreath-laying ceremony at Flanders Field Cemetery in Brussels, Belgium, on Wednesday.

item.title: Jurors Convict Abu Ghaith, Bin Laden Son-in-Law, in Terror Case
item.description: Sulaiman Abu Ghaith’s swift conviction is seen as a rejoinder to critics of the Obama administration’s efforts to try terror suspects in civilian courts, rather than before a military tribunal.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER
item.media:description: Sulaiman Abu Ghaith had recorded impassioned speeches for Osama bin Laden after Sept. 11.

item.title: Putting 2 Sons in Top Posts, Murdoch Guards His Dynasty
item.description: Lachlan Murdoch became nonexecutive co-chairman of the News Corporation and 21st Century Fox, and James Murdoch became co-chief operating officer at 21st Century Fox.
item.dc:creator: By RAVI SOMAIYA, DAVID CARR and BROOKS BARNES
item.media:description: Lachlan Murdoch, left, earlier this month with his father, Rupert, and brother, James.

item.title: World Briefing: Guinea: Government Bans Bat Soup to Halt Ebola Outbreak
item.description: The action came after the West African nation’s first Ebola outbreak, which has killed 63 people.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: News Analysis: Facing a War Crimes Inquiry, Sri Lanka Continues to Vex the U.N.
item.description: The U.N. Human Rights Council will vote Thursday on whether to proceed with an investigation into possible abuses during Sri Lanka’s civil war, a move its government is fighting.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Buddhist monks in Sri Lanka holding prayers in the capital, Colombo, seeking the defeat of a vote for a United Nations inquiry.

item.title: General Who Led Takeover of Egypt to Run for President
item.description: Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi, who pushed President Mohamed Morsi out of office last year, is expected to win and formalize the power he currently holds as the government’s top decision maker.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi promised Wednesday that he would soon offer “a clear platform for a modern and democratic Egypt.”

item.title: Danish Zoo Reviled in the Death of a Giraffe Kills 4 Lions
item.description: The zoo is the same one where a young giraffe was killed last month, then dissected and fed to lions — among them, the four lions put down this week.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Lionesses on Wednesday in the Copenhagen Zoo, where two lions and their cubs were recently euthanized, stirring outrage.

item.title: Kerry in Jordan for Talks With Palestinian Leader
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry planned to meet with Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, in an effort to salvage Middle East peace talks.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry arrived in Amman, Jordan on Wednesday.

item.title: Pakistanis Said to Meet With Taliban to Lay Groundwork for More Talks
item.description: The meeting at a secret location in the militant bastion of North Waziristan was the first contact since efforts were derailed in February amid a barrage of terrorist attacks.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A Tortured Policy Toward Russia
item.description: The U.S. has to stop making threats that it can’t carry out.
item.dc:creator: By IAN BREMMER
